nodes.bodyText: you should remove final from all parameters
I don't really like this new HashMap<>() works as well
@szarnekow We prefer not to have there in the java code right?
True. catch(Throwable) is a bad sign in general.
@cdietrich We're 2.21 one now, is this still beta?
I'd like to keep this @Beta - the code tickles me. I've doubts that it is really safe to to do it like this.

nodes.bodyText: @cdietrich Is this still beta? It's been so long

Almost all implementations that I saw do need access to the issues. If we want to de-betarize this, we should consider passing the issues directly to this API. The caller would make sure that the issues are only computed once.
Nothing I can change here, right? It's protected.
Nope, sadly you can't do anything about this
Just remove every @Pure in this file
same, also it_1 is a pretty bad name
Fixed, but please have a look if you agree that I got the meaning right.
Not sure what to do with this ... any suggestion?
Not sure if out should better be buffered if it isn't already.
Not sure, too. As this is refactoring only I tend to not change behaviour.
Sure this should be an identity check?

Old generated code: if (((this.currentResource == null) || (source.eResource() != this.currentResource))) {
Hence: Yes, at least sure semantic has not changed.
I'd move this three lines lower
This used to be an InterruptedException

Static import this if there is no name collision

nodes.bodyText: Could be come Preconditions.checkNotNull(..) and the subsequent hashCode and equals implementation could be simplified.
It would be really useful if these would declare throws IOException
Not sure here about API consequences ... and what about BeforeRead and BeforeDelete!?

I tried to include beforeRead and beforeDelete in these.
Declaring an exception on the signature would be binary compatible, but source incompatible. However, since some the callbacks will be implemented with Xtend, it wouldn't matter (sneakyThrow ...). @cdietrich What's your take?
is there anybody out there using (calling) this at all?
maybe you can have a look at these
There is only a single field. We could try to avoid the ToStringBuilder
Severity is an enum - identity comparison could be used here.
